	<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">2010 United States House of Representatives elections</h1>
	<div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
		<div id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
		<div id="contentSub"></div>
		<div id="contentSub2"></div>
		
		<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
		<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
		<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
		<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">House elections for the 112th U.S. Congress</div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">For related races, see <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_elections" title="2010 United States elections">2010 United States elections</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>

</tbody></table></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;text-align:center;"><hr /><a href="/wiki/File:2010_House_elections.svg" class="image"><img alt="2010 House elections.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/2010_House_elections.svg/320px-2010_House_elections.svg.png" decoding="async" width="320" height="193" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/2010_House_elections.svg/480px-2010_House_elections.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/2010_House_elections.svg/640px-2010_House_elections.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="2583" data-file-height="1557" /></a><div><b>Results:</b><br /><span style="margin:0px; font-size:90%;"><span style="border:none; background-color:#92C5DE; color:#92C5DE;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</span>&#160;Democratic hold</span> <span style="margin:0px; font-size:90%;"><span style="border:none; background-color:#0671B0; color:#0671B0;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</span>&#160;Democratic gain</span><br /><span style="margin:0px; font-size:90%;"><span style="border:none; background-color:#F48882; color:#F48882;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</span>&#160;Republican hold</span> <span style="margin:0px; font-size:90%;"><span style="border:none; background-color:#CA0120; color:#CA0120;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</span>&#160;Republican gain</span></div></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;text-align:center;"><hr />
<table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="background:transparent; width:100%;">
<tbody><tr>
<td style="width:50%; text-align:left;"><b><a href="/wiki/Speaker_of_the_United_States_House_of_Representatives" title="Speaker of the United States House of Representatives">Speaker</a> before election</b><br />
<p><a href="/wiki/Nancy_Pelosi" title="Nancy Pelosi">Nancy Pelosi</a><br />
<a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(US)" class="mw-redirect" title="Democratic Party (US)">Democratic</a>
</p>
</td>
<td style="width:50%; text-align:right;"><b>Elected <a href="/wiki/Speaker_of_the_United_States_House_of_Representatives" title="Speaker of the United States House of Representatives">Speaker</a></b> <br />
<p><a href="/wiki/John_Boehner" title="John Boehner">John Boehner</a><br />
<a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(US)" class="mw-redirect" title="Republican Party (US)">Republican</a>
</p>
</td></tr></tbody></table></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <b>2010 United States House of Representatives elections</b> were held on November 2, 2010 as part of the <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_elections" title="2010 United States elections">2010 midterm elections</a> during President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a>'s first term in office. Voters of the 50 <a href="/wiki/U.S._state" title="U.S. state">U.S. states</a> chose 435 <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives" title="United States House of Representatives">U.S. Representatives</a>. Also, voters of the U.S. territories, commonwealths, and the District of Columbia chose their <a href="/wiki/Delegate_(United_States_Congress)" class="mw-redirect" title="Delegate (United States Congress)">non-voting delegates</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;b&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_elections" title="2010 United States Senate elections">U.S. Senate elections</a> and various state and local elections were held on the same date.
</p><p>Republicans regained control of the chamber they had lost in the <a href="/wiki/2006_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections" title="2006 United States House of Representatives elections">2006 midterm elections</a>, picking up a net total of 63 seats and erasing the gains Democrats made in 2006 and <a href="/wiki/2008_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections" title="2008 United States House of Representatives elections">2008</a>. Although the sitting U.S. President's party usually loses seats in a midterm election, the 2010 election resulted in the highest losses by a party in a House midterm election since <a href="/wiki/1938_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections" title="1938 United States House of Representatives elections">1938</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> and the largest House swing since <a href="/wiki/1948_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections" title="1948 United States House of Representatives elections">1948</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> Republicans made their largest gain in House seats since <a href="/wiki/1938_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections" title="1938 United States House of Representatives elections">1938</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The heavy Democratic Party losses in 2010 were attributed to anger at President Obama, opposition to the <a href="/wiki/Affordable_Care_Act" title="Affordable Care Act">Affordable Care Act</a>, large budget deficits and the weak economy.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#Incumbents_defeated"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Incumbents defeated</span></a>
<ul>

</li>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Background">Background</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Background">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Boehner_for_Speaker_Bumper_Sticker.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cb/Boehner_for_Speaker_Bumper_Sticker.jpg/260px-Boehner_for_Speaker_Bumper_Sticker.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cb/Boehner_for_Speaker_Bumper_Sticker.jpg/390px-Boehner_for_Speaker_Bumper_Sticker.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cb/Boehner_for_Speaker_Bumper_Sticker.jpg/520px-Boehner_for_Speaker_Bumper_Sticker.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1456" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Boehner_for_Speaker_Bumper_Sticker.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An anti-Pelosi "Boehner for Speaker" bumper sticker on a car window.</div></div></div>
<p>Following the <a href="/wiki/2006_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections" title="2006 United States House of Representatives elections">2006 elections</a>, Democrats took control of the House as well as the Senate. In the <a href="/wiki/2008_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections" title="2008 United States House of Representatives elections">2008 elections</a>, which coincided with Democrat <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a>'s <a href="/wiki/2008_United_States_presidential_election" title="2008 United States presidential election">victory</a> over Republican <a href="/wiki/John_McCain" title="John McCain">John McCain</a> for the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">presidency</a>, Democrats increased their majorities in both chambers. Of the 435 congressional districts, 242 were carried by Obama, while 193 voted for McCain. Of the districts Obama won, 34 elected a Republican to the House, while 49 of the districts McCain won elected a Democrat.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Republican_gains">Republican gains</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Republican gains">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The Republicans' 63-seat pickup in the House to take control of that chamber, as well as their gain of six Senate seats, signified a dramatic rollback of recent Democratic gains. In the election, Republicans won their greatest number of House seats since 1946.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> This has been attributed to the continued economic recession, as well as President Obama's controversial <a href="/wiki/American_Recovery_and_Reinvestment_Act_of_2009" title="American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009">stimulus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act" class="mw-redirect" title="Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act">health care reform</a> bills. Republicans also took control of 29 of the 50 state governorships and gained 690 seats in state legislatures, to hold their greatest number since the 1928 elections.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Republicans also made historic gains in <a href="/wiki/State_legislature_(United_States)" title="State legislature (United States)">state legislatures</a>, adding more than 675 state legislative seats, by far surpassing their state-legislative gains in 1994.<sup id="cite_ref-NCSL_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NCSL-18">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Balz_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Balz-19">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> Republicans gained control of dozens of state legislative chambers,<sup id="cite_ref-NCSL_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NCSL-18">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> and took control of "seven more legislatures outright than they did after 1994 and the most since 1952."<sup id="cite_ref-Balz_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Balz-19">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> Republicans picked up control of the <a href="/wiki/Alabama_Legislature" title="Alabama Legislature">Alabama Legislature</a> for the first time since <a href="/wiki/Reconstruction_era_in_the_United_States" class="mw-redirect" title="Reconstruction era in the United States">Reconstruction</a>; control of the <a href="/wiki/North_Carolina_Senate" title="North Carolina Senate">North Carolina Senate</a> for the first time since 1870; and control of the <a href="/wiki/Minnesota_Senate" title="Minnesota Senate">Minnesota Senate</a> for the first time since the state returned to partisan elections in 1974.<sup id="cite_ref-NCSL_18-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NCSL-18">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Balz_19-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Balz-19">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes_region" title="Great Lakes region">Great Lakes region</a>, which until then had recently favored the Democratic Party, went strongly Republican. In California and the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Northwest" title="Pacific Northwest">Pacific Northwest</a>, however, the Democrats retained the upper hand.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> The biggest change in 2010 occurred in the Southeastern United States, which had previously been roughly evenly split between Democrats and Republicans for everything except for president. Just one white Democrat from the Deep South won reelection to the US House in 2010. Prior to 2010, many white conservative southerners had voted Republican for president, but Democratic for other offices.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Results_summary">Results summary</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Results summary">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Retiring_incumbents">Retiring incumbents</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Retiring incumbents">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Thirty-seven incumbents retired.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Democrats">Democrats</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Democrats">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Seventeen incumbent Democrats retired.
</p>
<ul><li><span data-sort-value="Alabama07&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Alabama%27s_7th_congressional_district" title="Alabama&#39;s 7th congressional district">Alabama&#160;7</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Artur_Davis" title="Artur Davis">Artur Davis</a>: To <a href="/wiki/2010_Alabama_gubernatorial_election" title="2010 Alabama gubernatorial election">run for Governor of Alabama</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-23">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Arkansas01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Arkansas%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="Arkansas&#39;s 1st congressional district">Arkansas&#160;1</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Robert_Marion_Berry" title="Robert Marion Berry">Marion Berry</a>: Retired due to health concerns.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Arkansas02&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Arkansas%27s_2nd_congressional_district" title="Arkansas&#39;s 2nd congressional district">Arkansas&#160;2</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Vic_Snyder" title="Vic Snyder">Vic Snyder</a>: Retired to spend more time with family.<sup id="cite_ref-snyder_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-snyder-25">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="California33&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/California%27s_33rd_congressional_district" title="California&#39;s 33rd congressional district">California&#160;33</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Diane_Watson" title="Diane Watson">Diane Watson</a>: Retired; "It should be a seat inherited by someone who can represent everyone in this district."<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Florida17&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Florida%27s_17th_congressional_district" title="Florida&#39;s 17th congressional district">Florida&#160;17</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Kendrick_Meek" title="Kendrick Meek">Kendrick Meek</a>: To <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_election_in_Florida" title="2010 United States Senate election in Florida">run for U.S. Senator</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-thehill1_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thehill1-27">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Indiana08&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Indiana%27s_8th_congressional_district" title="Indiana&#39;s 8th congressional district">Indiana&#160;8</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Brad_Ellsworth" title="Brad Ellsworth">Brad Ellsworth</a>: To <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_election_in_Indiana" title="2010 United States Senate election in Indiana">run for U.S. Senator</a>.</li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Kansas03&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Kansas%27s_3rd_congressional_district" title="Kansas&#39;s 3rd congressional district">Kansas&#160;3</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Dennis_Moore_(politician)" title="Dennis Moore (politician)">Dennis Moore</a>: Retired; "Time for a new generation of leadership."<sup id="cite_ref-moore_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-moore-28">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Louisiana03&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Louisiana%27s_3rd_congressional_district" title="Louisiana&#39;s 3rd congressional district">Louisiana&#160;3</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Melan%C3%A7on" title="Charlie Melançon">Charlie Melançon</a>: To <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_election_in_Louisiana" title="2010 United States Senate election in Louisiana">run for U.S. Senator</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-melancon_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-melancon-29">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Massachusetts10&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Massachusetts%27s_10th_congressional_district" title="Massachusetts&#39;s 10th congressional district">Massachusetts&#160;10</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Bill_Delahunt" title="Bill Delahunt">Bill Delahunt</a>: Retired; "Life is about change. I think it's healthy. It's time."<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Michigan01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Michigan%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="Michigan&#39;s 1st congressional district">Michigan&#160;1</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Bart_Stupak" title="Bart Stupak">Bart Stupak</a>: Retired; "I've accomplished what I want to do."<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="New Hampshire02&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/New_Hampshire%27s_2nd_congressional_district" title="New Hampshire&#39;s 2nd congressional district">New Hampshire&#160;2</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Paul_Hodes" title="Paul Hodes">Paul Hodes</a>: To <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_election_in_New_Hampshire" title="2010 United States Senate election in New Hampshire">run for U.S. Senator</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-unionleader1_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unionleader1-32">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Pennsylvania07&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania%27s_7th_congressional_district" title="Pennsylvania&#39;s 7th congressional district">Pennsylvania&#160;7</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Joe_Sestak" title="Joe Sestak">Joe Sestak</a>: To <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_election_in_Pennsylvania" title="2010 United States Senate election in Pennsylvania">run for U.S. Senator</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sestak_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sestak-33">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Rhode Island01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Rhode_Island%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="Rhode Island&#39;s 1st congressional district">Rhode Island&#160;1</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Patrick_J._Kennedy" title="Patrick J. Kennedy">Patrick J. Kennedy</a>: Retired to "[take] a new direction."<sup id="cite_ref-kennedy_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kennedy-34">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Tennessee06&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Tennessee%27s_6th_congressional_district" title="Tennessee&#39;s 6th congressional district">Tennessee&#160;6</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Bart_Gordon" title="Bart Gordon">Bart Gordon</a>: Retired; "…it's time for a new chapter."<sup id="cite_ref-gordon_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gordon-35">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Tennessee08&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Tennessee%27s_8th_congressional_district" title="Tennessee&#39;s 8th congressional district">Tennessee&#160;8</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/John_S._Tanner" title="John S. Tanner">John S. Tanner</a>: Retired; decided 20 years was long enough.<sup id="cite_ref-tanner_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tanner-36">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Washington03&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Washington%27s_3rd_congressional_district" title="Washington&#39;s 3rd congressional district">Washington&#160;3</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Brian_Baird" title="Brian Baird">Brian Baird</a>: Retired, to pursue other options.<sup id="cite_ref-baird_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-baird-37">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Wisconsin07&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Wisconsin%27s_7th_congressional_district" title="Wisconsin&#39;s 7th congressional district">Wisconsin&#160;7</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Dave_Obey" title="Dave Obey">Dave Obey</a>: Retired; "But even more frankly, I am bone tired."<sup id="cite_ref-Obey_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Obey-38">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup> Media reports indicated Obey's future plans included joining a DC lobbying firm run by former Representative <a href="/wiki/Dick_Gephardt" title="Dick Gephardt">Dick Gephardt</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Obey2_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Obey2-39">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Republicans">Republicans</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Republicans">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Twenty incumbent Republicans retired.
</p>
<ul><li><span data-sort-value="Arkansas03&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Arkansas%27s_3rd_congressional_district" title="Arkansas&#39;s 3rd congressional district">Arkansas&#160;3</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/John_Boozman" title="John Boozman">John Boozman</a>: To <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_election_in_Arkansas" title="2010 United States Senate election in Arkansas">run for U.S. Senator</a>.</li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Arizona03&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Arizona%27s_3rd_congressional_district" title="Arizona&#39;s 3rd congressional district">Arizona&#160;3</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/John_Shadegg" title="John Shadegg">John Shadegg</a>: Retired to pursue other interests.<sup id="cite_ref-shadegg_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-shadegg-40">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="California19&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/California%27s_19th_congressional_district" title="California&#39;s 19th congressional district">California&#160;19</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/George_Radanovich" title="George Radanovich">George Radanovich</a>: Retired to put family obligations first.<sup id="cite_ref-radanovich_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-radanovich-41">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="DelawareAL&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Delaware%27s_at-large_congressional_district" title="Delaware&#39;s at-large congressional district">Delaware&#160;at-large</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Mike_Castle" title="Mike Castle">Mike Castle</a>: To <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_special_election_in_Delaware" title="2010 United States Senate special election in Delaware">run for U.S. Senator</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-castle_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-castle-42">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Florida05&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Florida%27s_5th_congressional_district" title="Florida&#39;s 5th congressional district">Florida&#160;5</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Ginny_Brown-Waite" title="Ginny Brown-Waite">Ginny Brown-Waite</a>: Retired due to health issues.<sup id="cite_ref-cillizza1_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cillizza1-43">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Florida12&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Florida%27s_12th_congressional_district" title="Florida&#39;s 12th congressional district">Florida&#160;12</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Adam_Putnam" title="Adam Putnam">Adam Putnam</a>: To run for <a href="/wiki/Florida_Commissioner_of_Agriculture" title="Florida Commissioner of Agriculture">Florida Commissioner of Agriculture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-thehill2_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thehill2-44">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Florida21&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Florida%27s_21st_congressional_district" title="Florida&#39;s 21st congressional district">Florida&#160;21</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_D%C3%ADaz-Balart" title="Lincoln Díaz-Balart">Lincoln Díaz-Balart</a>: Retired to return to law practice.</li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Florida25&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Florida%27s_25th_congressional_district" title="Florida&#39;s 25th congressional district">Florida&#160;25</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Mario_D%C3%ADaz-Balart" title="Mario Díaz-Balart">Mario Díaz-Balart</a>: To run for Florida's 21st district, held by his brother Lincoln Diaz-Balart, who had announced plans to return to law practice.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Georgia07&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Georgia%27s_7th_congressional_district" title="Georgia&#39;s 7th congressional district">Georgia&#160;7</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/John_Linder" title="John Linder">John Linder</a>: Retired.<sup id="cite_ref-Bob_Keefe_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bob_Keefe-46">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Illinois10&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Illinois%27s_10th_congressional_district" title="Illinois&#39;s 10th congressional district">Illinois&#160;10</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Mark_Kirk" title="Mark Kirk">Mark Kirk</a>: To <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_election_in_Illinois" class="mw-redirect" title="2010 United States Senate election in Illinois">run for U.S. Senator</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-kirk_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kirk-47">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Indiana04&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Indiana%27s_4th_congressional_district" title="Indiana&#39;s 4th congressional district">Indiana&#160;4</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Steve_Buyer" title="Steve Buyer">Steve Buyer</a>: Retired due to wife's illness<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Kansas01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Kansas%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="Kansas&#39;s 1st congressional district">Kansas&#160;1</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Jerry_Moran" title="Jerry Moran">Jerry Moran</a>: To <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_election_in_Kansas" title="2010 United States Senate election in Kansas">run for U.S. Senator</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MoranEagle_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MoranEagle-49">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Kansas04&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Kansas%27s_4th_congressional_district" title="Kansas&#39;s 4th congressional district">Kansas&#160;4</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Todd_Tiahrt" title="Todd Tiahrt">Todd Tiahrt</a>: To <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_election_in_Kansas" title="2010 United States Senate election in Kansas">run for U.S. Senator</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-thehill3_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thehill3-50">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Michigan02&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Michigan%27s_2nd_congressional_district" title="Michigan&#39;s 2nd congressional district">Michigan&#160;2</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Pete_Hoekstra" title="Pete Hoekstra">Pete Hoekstra</a>: To <a href="/wiki/2010_Michigan_gubernatorial_election" title="2010 Michigan gubernatorial election">run for Governor of Michigan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cqpolitics1_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cqpolitics1-51">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Michigan03&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Michigan%27s_3rd_congressional_district" title="Michigan&#39;s 3rd congressional district">Michigan&#160;3</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Vern_Ehlers" title="Vern Ehlers">Vern Ehlers</a>: Retired.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Missouri07&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Missouri%27s_7th_congressional_district" title="Missouri&#39;s 7th congressional district">Missouri&#160;7</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Roy_Blunt" title="Roy Blunt">Roy Blunt</a>: To <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_election_in_Missouri" title="2010 United States Senate election in Missouri">run for U.S. Senator</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-politico1_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-politico1-53">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Oklahoma05&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Oklahoma%27s_5th_congressional_district" title="Oklahoma&#39;s 5th congressional district">Oklahoma&#160;5</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Mary_Fallin" title="Mary Fallin">Mary Fallin</a>: To <a href="/wiki/2010_Oklahoma_gubernatorial_election" title="2010 Oklahoma gubernatorial election">run for Governor of Oklahoma</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-fallin_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fallin-54">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="South Carolina01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/South_Carolina%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="South Carolina&#39;s 1st congressional district">South Carolina&#160;1</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Henry_E._Brown_Jr." title="Henry E. Brown Jr.">Henry E. Brown Jr.</a>: Retired to spend more time with his family.<sup id="cite_ref-SCBrown_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SCBrown-55">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="South Carolina03&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/South_Carolina%27s_3rd_congressional_district" title="South Carolina&#39;s 3rd congressional district">South Carolina&#160;3</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Gresham_Barrett" title="Gresham Barrett">Gresham Barrett</a>: To <a href="/wiki/2010_South_Carolina_gubernatorial_election" title="2010 South Carolina gubernatorial election">run for Governor of South Carolina</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-thehill.com_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thehill.com-56">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Tennessee03&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Tennessee%27s_3rd_congressional_district" title="Tennessee&#39;s 3rd congressional district">Tennessee&#160;3</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Zach_Wamp" title="Zach Wamp">Zach Wamp</a>: To <a href="/wiki/2010_Tennessee_gubernatorial_election" title="2010 Tennessee gubernatorial election">run for Governor of Tennessee</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-timesfreepress1_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-timesfreepress1-57">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Incumbents_defeated">Incumbents defeated</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Incumbents defeated">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>There were nine Democrats who survived reelection in the <a href="/wiki/Republican_Revolution" title="Republican Revolution">1994 Republican Revolution</a>, but were defeated this year.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Lost_renomination">Lost renomination</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Lost renomination">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Democrats_2">Democrats</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Democrats">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Two Democrats lost renomination. One seat remained Democratic, and the other seat was taken by a Republican.
</p>
<ul><li><span data-sort-value="Michigan13&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Michigan%27s_13th_congressional_district" title="Michigan&#39;s 13th congressional district">Michigan&#160;13</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Carolyn_Cheeks_Kilpatrick" title="Carolyn Cheeks Kilpatrick">Carolyn Cheeks Kilpatrick</a> lost to <a href="/wiki/Hansen_Clarke" title="Hansen Clarke">Hansen Clarke</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="West Virginia01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/West_Virginia%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="West Virginia&#39;s 1st congressional district">West Virginia&#160;1</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Alan_Mollohan" title="Alan Mollohan">Alan Mollohan</a> lost to <a href="/wiki/Mike_Oliverio" title="Mike Oliverio">Mike Oliverio</a>, but Oliverio lost in the general election to Republican <a href="/wiki/David_McKinley" title="David McKinley">David McKinley</a></li></ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Republicans_2">Republicans</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Republicans">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Two Republicans lost renomination. Both seats remained Republican.
</p>
<ul><li><span data-sort-value="Alabama05&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Alabama%27s_5th_congressional_district" title="Alabama&#39;s 5th congressional district">Alabama&#160;5</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Parker_Griffith" title="Parker Griffith">Parker Griffith</a> (first elected in 2008 as a Democrat; switched parties in 2009) lost to <a href="/wiki/Mo_Brooks" title="Mo Brooks">Mo Brooks</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="South Carolina04&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/South_Carolina%27s_4th_congressional_district" title="South Carolina&#39;s 4th congressional district">South Carolina&#160;4</a></span>: <a href="/wiki/Bob_Inglis" title="Bob Inglis">Bob Inglis</a> lost to <a href="/wiki/Trey_Gowdy" title="Trey Gowdy">Trey Gowdy</a></li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Lost_re-election">Lost re-election</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Lost re-election">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Fifty-four incumbents lost in the general election; all but two were Democrats. Many of the Democrats who lost had been initially elected in the Democratic wave years of 2006 and 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-Houseelec_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Houseelec-58">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Democrats_3">Democrats</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Democrats">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>52 Democrats lost re-election.
</p>
<ul><li><span data-sort-value="Alabama02&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Alabama%27s_2nd_congressional_district" title="Alabama&#39;s 2nd congressional district">Alabama&#160;2</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Bobby_Bright" title="Bobby Bright">Bobby Bright</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Martha_Roby" title="Martha Roby">Martha Roby</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Arizona01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Arizona%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="Arizona&#39;s 1st congressional district">Arizona&#160;1</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Ann_Kirkpatrick" title="Ann Kirkpatrick">Ann Kirkpatrick</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Paul_Gosar" title="Paul Gosar">Paul Gosar</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Arizona05&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Arizona%27s_5th_congressional_district" title="Arizona&#39;s 5th congressional district">Arizona&#160;5</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Harry_Mitchell" title="Harry Mitchell">Harry Mitchell</a> (first elected in 2006) lost to <a href="/wiki/David_Schweikert" title="David Schweikert">David Schweikert</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Colorado03&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Colorado%27s_3rd_congressional_district" title="Colorado&#39;s 3rd congressional district">Colorado&#160;3</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/John_Salazar" title="John Salazar">John Salazar</a> (first elected in 2004) lost to <a href="/wiki/Scott_Tipton" title="Scott Tipton">Scott Tipton</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Colorado04&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Colorado%27s_4th_congressional_district" title="Colorado&#39;s 4th congressional district">Colorado&#160;4</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Betsy_Markey" title="Betsy Markey">Betsy Markey</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Cory_Gardner" title="Cory Gardner">Cory Gardner</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Florida02&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Florida%27s_2nd_congressional_district" title="Florida&#39;s 2nd congressional district">Florida&#160;2</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Allen_Boyd" title="Allen Boyd">Allen Boyd</a> (first elected in 1996) lost to <a href="/wiki/Steve_Southerland_(Florida_politician)" title="Steve Southerland (Florida politician)">Steve Southerland</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Florida08&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Florida%27s_8th_congressional_district" title="Florida&#39;s 8th congressional district">Florida&#160;8</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Alan_Grayson" title="Alan Grayson">Alan Grayson</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Webster_(Florida_politician)" title="Daniel Webster (Florida politician)">Daniel Webster</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Florida22&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Florida%27s_22nd_congressional_district" title="Florida&#39;s 22nd congressional district">Florida&#160;22</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Ron_Klein" title="Ron Klein">Ron Klein</a> (first elected in 2006) lost to <a href="/wiki/Allen_West_(politician)" title="Allen West (politician)">Allen West</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Florida24&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Florida%27s_24th_congressional_district" title="Florida&#39;s 24th congressional district">Florida&#160;24</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Suzanne_Kosmas" title="Suzanne Kosmas">Suzanne Kosmas</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Sandy_Adams" title="Sandy Adams">Sandy Adams</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Georgia08&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Georgia%27s_8th_congressional_district" title="Georgia&#39;s 8th congressional district">Georgia&#160;8</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Jim_Marshall_(Georgia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Jim Marshall (Georgia)">Jim Marshall</a> (first elected in 2002) lost to <a href="/wiki/Austin_Scott_(politician)" title="Austin Scott (politician)">Austin Scott</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Idaho01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Idaho%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="Idaho&#39;s 1st congressional district">Idaho&#160;1</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Walt_Minnick" title="Walt Minnick">Walt Minnick</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_Labrador" title="Raúl Labrador">Raúl Labrador</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Illinois08&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Illinois%27s_8th_congressional_district" title="Illinois&#39;s 8th congressional district">Illinois&#160;8</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Melissa_Bean" title="Melissa Bean">Melissa Bean</a> (first elected in 2004) lost to <a href="/wiki/Joe_Walsh_(Illinois_politician)" class="mw-redirect" title="Joe Walsh (Illinois politician)">Joe Walsh</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Illinois11&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Illinois%27s_11th_congressional_district" title="Illinois&#39;s 11th congressional district">Illinois&#160;11</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Debbie_Halvorson" title="Debbie Halvorson">Debbie Halvorson</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Adam_Kinzinger" title="Adam Kinzinger">Adam Kinzinger</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Illinois14&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Illinois%27s_14th_congressional_district" title="Illinois&#39;s 14th congressional district">Illinois&#160;14</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Bill_Foster_(Illinois_politician)" class="mw-redirect" title="Bill Foster (Illinois politician)">Bill Foster</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Randy_Hultgren" title="Randy Hultgren">Randy Hultgren</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Illinois17&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Illinois%27s_17th_congressional_district" title="Illinois&#39;s 17th congressional district">Illinois&#160;17</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Phil_Hare" title="Phil Hare">Phil Hare</a> (first elected in 2006) lost to <a href="/wiki/Bobby_Schilling" title="Bobby Schilling">Bobby Schilling</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Indiana09&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Indiana%27s_9th_congressional_district" title="Indiana&#39;s 9th congressional district">Indiana&#160;9</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Baron_Hill_(politician)" title="Baron Hill (politician)">Baron Hill</a> (originally elected in 1998) lost to <a href="/wiki/Todd_Young" title="Todd Young">Todd Young</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Maryland01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Maryland%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="Maryland&#39;s 1st congressional district">Maryland&#160;1</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Frank_Kratovil" title="Frank Kratovil">Frank Kratovil</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Andrew_P._Harris" class="mw-redirect" title="Andrew P. Harris">Andrew P. Harris</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Michigan07&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Michigan%27s_7th_congressional_district" title="Michigan&#39;s 7th congressional district">Michigan&#160;7</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Mark_Schauer" title="Mark Schauer">Mark Schauer</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Tim_Walberg" title="Tim Walberg">Tim Walberg</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Minnesota08&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Minnesota%27s_8th_congressional_district" title="Minnesota&#39;s 8th congressional district">Minnesota&#160;8</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Jim_Oberstar" title="Jim Oberstar">Jim Oberstar</a> (first elected in 1974) lost to <a href="/wiki/Chip_Cravaack" title="Chip Cravaack">Chip Cravaack</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Mississippi01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Mississippi%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="Mississippi&#39;s 1st congressional district">Mississippi&#160;1</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Travis_Childers" title="Travis Childers">Travis Childers</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Alan_Nunnelee" title="Alan Nunnelee">Alan Nunnelee</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Mississippi04&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Mississippi%27s_4th_congressional_district" title="Mississippi&#39;s 4th congressional district">Mississippi&#160;4</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Gene_Taylor_(Mississippi)" class="mw-redirect" title="Gene Taylor (Mississippi)">Gene Taylor</a> (first elected in 1989) lost to <a href="/wiki/Steven_Palazzo" title="Steven Palazzo">Steven Palazzo</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Missouri04&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Missouri%27s_4th_congressional_district" title="Missouri&#39;s 4th congressional district">Missouri&#160;4</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Ike_Skelton" title="Ike Skelton">Ike Skelton</a> (first elected in 1976) lost to <a href="/wiki/Vicky_Hartzler" title="Vicky Hartzler">Vicky Hartzler</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Nevada03&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Nevada%27s_3rd_congressional_district" title="Nevada&#39;s 3rd congressional district">Nevada&#160;3</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Dina_Titus" title="Dina Titus">Dina Titus</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Joe_Heck" title="Joe Heck">Joe Heck</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="New Hampshire01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/New_Hampshire%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="New Hampshire&#39;s 1st congressional district">New Hampshire&#160;1</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Carol_Shea-Porter" title="Carol Shea-Porter">Carol Shea-Porter</a> (first elected in 2006) lost to <a href="/wiki/Frank_Guinta" title="Frank Guinta">Frank Guinta</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="New Jersey03&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/New_Jersey%27s_3rd_congressional_district" title="New Jersey&#39;s 3rd congressional district">New Jersey&#160;3</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/John_Adler" title="John Adler">John Adler</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Jon_Runyan" title="Jon Runyan">Jon Runyan</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="New Mexico02&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/New_Mexico%27s_2nd_congressional_district" title="New Mexico&#39;s 2nd congressional district">New Mexico&#160;2</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Harry_Teague" title="Harry Teague">Harry Teague</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Steve_Pearce_(politician)" title="Steve Pearce (politician)">Steve Pearce</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="New York13&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/New_York%27s_13th_congressional_district" title="New York&#39;s 13th congressional district">New York&#160;13</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_McMahon" title="Michael McMahon">Michael McMahon</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Michael_Grimm_(politician)" title="Michael Grimm (politician)">Michael Grimm</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="New York19&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/New_York%27s_19th_congressional_district" title="New York&#39;s 19th congressional district">New York&#160;19</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/John_Hall_(U.S._politician)" class="mw-redirect" title="John Hall (U.S. politician)">John Hall</a> (first elected in 2006) lost to <a href="/wiki/Nan_Hayworth" title="Nan Hayworth">Nan Hayworth</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="New York20&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/New_York%27s_20th_congressional_district" title="New York&#39;s 20th congressional district">New York&#160;20</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Scott_Murphy" title="Scott Murphy">Scott Murphy</a> (first elected in 2009) lost to <a href="/wiki/Chris_Gibson_(New_York_politician)" title="Chris Gibson (New York politician)">Chris Gibson</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="New York24&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/New_York%27s_24th_congressional_district" title="New York&#39;s 24th congressional district">New York&#160;24</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Mike_Arcuri" title="Mike Arcuri">Mike Arcuri</a> (first elected in 2006) lost to <a href="/wiki/Richard_L._Hanna" title="Richard L. Hanna">Richard L. Hanna</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="New York25&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/New_York%27s_25th_congressional_district" title="New York&#39;s 25th congressional district">New York&#160;25</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Dan_Maffei" title="Dan Maffei">Dan Maffei</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Ann_Marie_Buerkle" title="Ann Marie Buerkle">Ann Marie Buerkle</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="North Carolina02&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/North_Carolina%27s_2nd_congressional_district" title="North Carolina&#39;s 2nd congressional district">North Carolina&#160;2</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Bob_Etheridge" title="Bob Etheridge">Bob Etheridge</a> (first elected in 1996) lost to <a href="/wiki/Renee_Ellmers" title="Renee Ellmers">Renee Ellmers</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="North DakotaAL&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/North_Dakota%27s_at-large_congressional_district" title="North Dakota&#39;s at-large congressional district">North Dakota&#160;at-large</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Earl_Pomeroy" title="Earl Pomeroy">Earl Pomeroy</a> (first elected in 1992) lost to <a href="/wiki/Rick_Berg" title="Rick Berg">Rick Berg</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Ohio01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Ohio%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="Ohio&#39;s 1st congressional district">Ohio&#160;1</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Steve_Driehaus" title="Steve Driehaus">Steve Driehaus</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Steve_Chabot" title="Steve Chabot">Steve Chabot</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Ohio06&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Ohio%27s_6th_congressional_district" title="Ohio&#39;s 6th congressional district">Ohio&#160;6</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Wilson_(Ohio_politician)" title="Charlie Wilson (Ohio politician)">Charlie Wilson</a> (first elected in 2006) lost to <a href="/wiki/Bill_Johnson_(Ohio_politician)" title="Bill Johnson (Ohio politician)">Bill Johnson</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Ohio15&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Ohio%27s_15th_congressional_district" title="Ohio&#39;s 15th congressional district">Ohio&#160;15</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Mary_Jo_Kilroy" title="Mary Jo Kilroy">Mary Jo Kilroy</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Steve_Stivers" title="Steve Stivers">Steve Stivers</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Ohio16&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Ohio%27s_16th_congressional_district" title="Ohio&#39;s 16th congressional district">Ohio&#160;16</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/John_Boccieri" title="John Boccieri">John Boccieri</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Jim_Renacci" title="Jim Renacci">Jim Renacci</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Ohio18&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Ohio%27s_18th_congressional_district" title="Ohio&#39;s 18th congressional district">Ohio&#160;18</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Zack_Space" title="Zack Space">Zack Space</a> (first elected in 2006) lost to <a href="/wiki/Bob_Gibbs" title="Bob Gibbs">Bob Gibbs</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Pennsylvania03&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania%27s_3rd_congressional_district" title="Pennsylvania&#39;s 3rd congressional district">Pennsylvania&#160;3</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Kathy_Dahlkemper" title="Kathy Dahlkemper">Kathy Dahlkemper</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Mike_Kelly_(Pennsylvania)" class="mw-redirect" title="Mike Kelly (Pennsylvania)">Mike Kelly</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Pennsylvania08&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania%27s_8th_congressional_district" title="Pennsylvania&#39;s 8th congressional district">Pennsylvania&#160;8</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Murphy_(Pennsylvania_politician)" title="Patrick Murphy (Pennsylvania politician)">Patrick Murphy</a> (first elected in 2006) lost to <a href="/wiki/Mike_Fitzpatrick" title="Mike Fitzpatrick">Mike Fitzpatrick</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Pennsylvania10&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania%27s_10th_congressional_district" title="Pennsylvania&#39;s 10th congressional district">Pennsylvania&#160;10</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Chris_Carney" title="Chris Carney">Chris Carney</a> (first elected in 2006) lost to <a href="/wiki/Tom_Marino" title="Tom Marino">Tom Marino</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Pennsylvania11&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania%27s_11th_congressional_district" title="Pennsylvania&#39;s 11th congressional district">Pennsylvania&#160;11</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Paul_E._Kanjorski" class="mw-redirect" title="Paul E. Kanjorski">Paul E. Kanjorski</a> (first elected in 1984) lost to <a href="/wiki/Lou_Barletta" title="Lou Barletta">Lou Barletta</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="South Carolina05&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/South_Carolina%27s_5th_congressional_district" title="South Carolina&#39;s 5th congressional district">South Carolina&#160;5</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/John_Spratt" title="John Spratt">John Spratt</a> (first elected in 1982) lost to <a href="/wiki/Mick_Mulvaney" title="Mick Mulvaney">Mick Mulvaney</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="South DakotaAL&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/South_Dakota%27s_at-large_congressional_district" title="South Dakota&#39;s at-large congressional district">South Dakota&#160;at-large</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Stephanie_Herseth_Sandlin" title="Stephanie Herseth Sandlin">Stephanie Herseth Sandlin</a> (first elected in 2004) lost to <a href="/wiki/Kristi_Noem" title="Kristi Noem">Kristi Noem</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Tennessee04&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Tennessee%27s_4th_congressional_district" title="Tennessee&#39;s 4th congressional district">Tennessee&#160;4</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Davis" title="Lincoln Davis">Lincoln Davis</a> (first elected in 2002) lost to <a href="/wiki/Scott_DesJarlais" title="Scott DesJarlais">Scott DesJarlais</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Texas17&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Texas%27s_17th_congressional_district" title="Texas&#39;s 17th congressional district">Texas&#160;17</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Chet_Edwards" title="Chet Edwards">Chet Edwards</a> (first elected in 1990) lost to <a href="/wiki/Bill_Flores" title="Bill Flores">Bill Flores</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Texas23&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Texas%27s_23rd_congressional_district" title="Texas&#39;s 23rd congressional district">Texas&#160;23</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Ciro_Rodriguez" title="Ciro Rodriguez">Ciro Rodriguez</a> (originally elected in 1996) lost to <a href="/wiki/Quico_Canseco" title="Quico Canseco">Quico Canseco</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Texas27&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Texas%27s_27th_congressional_district" title="Texas&#39;s 27th congressional district">Texas&#160;27</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Solomon_P._Ortiz" title="Solomon P. Ortiz">Solomon P. Ortiz</a> (first elected in 1982) lost to <a href="/wiki/Blake_Farenthold" title="Blake Farenthold">Blake Farenthold</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Virginia02&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Virginia%27s_2nd_congressional_district" title="Virginia&#39;s 2nd congressional district">Virginia&#160;2</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Glenn_Nye" title="Glenn Nye">Glenn Nye</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Scott_Rigell" title="Scott Rigell">Scott Rigell</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Virginia05&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Virginia%27s_5th_congressional_district" title="Virginia&#39;s 5th congressional district">Virginia&#160;5</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Perriello" title="Tom Perriello">Tom Perriello</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Robert_Hurt_(politician)" title="Robert Hurt (politician)">Robert Hurt</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Virginia09&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Virginia%27s_9th_congressional_district" title="Virginia&#39;s 9th congressional district">Virginia&#160;9</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Rick_Boucher" title="Rick Boucher">Rick Boucher</a> (first elected in 1982) lost to <a href="/wiki/Morgan_Griffith" title="Morgan Griffith">Morgan Griffith</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Wisconsin08&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Wisconsin%27s_8th_congressional_district" title="Wisconsin&#39;s 8th congressional district">Wisconsin&#160;8</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Steve_Kagen" title="Steve Kagen">Steve Kagen</a> (first elected in 2006) lost to <a href="/wiki/Reid_Ribble" title="Reid Ribble">Reid Ribble</a></li></ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Republicans_3">Republicans</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Republicans">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Two Republicans lost re-election.
</p>
<ul><li><span data-sort-value="Hawaii01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Hawaii%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="Hawaii&#39;s 1st congressional district">Hawaii&#160;1</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Charles_Djou" title="Charles Djou">Charles Djou</a> (first elected in 2010) lost to <a href="/wiki/Colleen_Hanabusa" title="Colleen Hanabusa">Colleen Hanabusa</a></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Louisiana02&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Louisiana%27s_2nd_congressional_district" title="Louisiana&#39;s 2nd congressional district">Louisiana&#160;2</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Cao" title="Joseph Cao">Joseph Cao</a> (first elected in 2008) lost to <a href="/wiki/Cedric_Richmond" title="Cedric Richmond">Cedric Richmond</a></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Open_seat_gains">Open seat gains</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Open seat gains">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Democratic_to_Republican">Democratic to Republican</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Democratic to Republican">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Fourteen open seats, held by Democrats, were won by Republicans.
</p>
<ul><li><span data-sort-value="Arkansas01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Arkansas%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="Arkansas&#39;s 1st congressional district">Arkansas&#160;1</a></span></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Arkansas02&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Arkansas%27s_2nd_congressional_district" title="Arkansas&#39;s 2nd congressional district">Arkansas&#160;2</a></span></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Indiana08&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Indiana%27s_8th_congressional_district" title="Indiana&#39;s 8th congressional district">Indiana&#160;8</a></span></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Kansas03&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Kansas%27s_3rd_congressional_district" title="Kansas&#39;s 3rd congressional district">Kansas&#160;3</a></span></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Louisiana03&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Louisiana%27s_3rd_congressional_district" title="Louisiana&#39;s 3rd congressional district">Louisiana&#160;3</a></span></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Michigan01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Michigan%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="Michigan&#39;s 1st congressional district">Michigan&#160;1</a></span></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="New Hampshire02&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/New_Hampshire%27s_2nd_congressional_district" title="New Hampshire&#39;s 2nd congressional district">New Hampshire&#160;2</a></span></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="New York29&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/New_York%27s_29th_congressional_district" title="New York&#39;s 29th congressional district">New York&#160;29</a></span></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Pennsylvania07&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania%27s_7th_congressional_district" title="Pennsylvania&#39;s 7th congressional district">Pennsylvania&#160;7</a></span></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Tennessee06&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Tennessee%27s_6th_congressional_district" title="Tennessee&#39;s 6th congressional district">Tennessee&#160;6</a></span></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Tennessee08&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Tennessee%27s_8th_congressional_district" title="Tennessee&#39;s 8th congressional district">Tennessee&#160;8</a></span></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Washington03&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Washington%27s_3rd_congressional_district" title="Washington&#39;s 3rd congressional district">Washington&#160;3</a></span></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="West Virginia01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/West_Virginia%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="West Virginia&#39;s 1st congressional district">West Virginia&#160;1</a></span></li>
<li><span data-sort-value="Wisconsin07&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Wisconsin%27s_7th_congressional_district" title="Wisconsin&#39;s 7th congressional district">Wisconsin&#160;7</a></span></li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Republican_to_Democratic">Republican to Democratic</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Republican to Democratic">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>One open seat, held by a Republican, was won by a Democrat.
</p>
<ul><li><span data-sort-value="DelawareAL&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Delaware%27s_at-large_congressional_district" title="Delaware&#39;s at-large congressional district">Delaware&#160;at-large</a></span></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Predictions">Predictions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Predictions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:House_Ratings_Data_Wiki.svg" class="image"><img alt="House Ratings Data Wiki.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/House_Ratings_Data_Wiki.svg/220px-House_Ratings_Data_Wiki.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="285" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/House_Ratings_Data_Wiki.svg/330px-House_Ratings_Data_Wiki.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/House_Ratings_Data_Wiki.svg/440px-House_Ratings_Data_Wiki.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="765" data-file-height="990" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:House_Ratings_Data_Wiki.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>These were predictions of the outcome of the 2010 United States House of Representatives elections.
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/RealClearPolitics" title="RealClearPolitics">RealClearPolitics</a>.
<ul><li>As of November 2, 2010, RCP projected the Republicans would take 224 seats, the Democrats would take 167, and 44 races were toss-ups.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nate_Silver" title="Nate Silver">Nate Silver</a>, FiveThirtyEight (New York Times)
<ul><li>As of November 2, 2010, Nate Silver's prediction model projected the Republicans would win (on average) 232.2 seats, and the Democrats would win 202.8.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Patrick_Ishmael&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Patrick Ishmael (page does not exist)">Patrick Ishmael</a>, Hot Air.com
<ul><li>Ishmael predicted on October 31, 2010, that Republicans would win a net of 63 seats, +/- 3 seats.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup> Rasmussen Reports cited Ishmael's calls in its election preview.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> The week before, Ishmael predicted a net Republican pickup of 62–65 seats.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Sabato%27s_Crystal_Ball" title="Sabato&#39;s Crystal Ball">Crystal Ball</a>
<ul><li>As of November 1, 2010, Larry Sabato predicted, "If the election were held today: + 55 Republican House seats".<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Charlie_Cook" title="Charlie Cook">Charlie Cook</a>
<ul><li>On October 26, 2010, The Cook Political Report raised its House forecast to "a Democratic net loss of 48 to 60 seats, with higher losses possible."<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>In a February 2010 interview with <i><a href="/wiki/National_Journal" title="National Journal">National Journal</a></i>, he said that "it's very hard to come up with a scenario where Democrats don't lose the House. It's very hard."<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Rasmussen_Reports" title="Rasmussen Reports">Rasmussen Reports</a>
<ul><li>On November 1, 2010, Scott Rasmussen predicted the Democrats "will likely lose 55 or more seats in the House."<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Rothenberg_Political_Report" class="mw-redirect" title="Rothenberg Political Report">Rothenberg Political Report</a>.
<ul><li>On October 28, 2010, Rothenberg Political Report predicted "Likely Republican gain of 55–65 seats, with gains at or above 70 seats possible."<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>In April 2010, <a href="/wiki/Stuart_Rothenberg" title="Stuart Rothenberg">Stuart Rothenberg</a> wrote on his <a href="/wiki/Blog" title="Blog">blog</a> that "…the atmospherics remain strongly behind the GOP, and major Republican House gains are extremely likely" and that "it's clear that the battleground is almost entirely on Democratic soil. Obviously, control of the House is at risk."<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Congressional_Quarterly" title="Congressional Quarterly">Congressional Quarterly</a>.
<ul><li>In October 2010, Congressional Quarterly projected the Democrats would take 195 seats, the Republicans 199, and they considered 41 races too close to call.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>In July 2010, Congressional Quarterly projected the Democrats would take 205 seats, the Republicans 190, and they considered 40 races too close to call.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup></li></ul></li></ul>
<p>The following table contains the final ratings of the competitiveness of selected races according to noted political analysts. Races which were considered safe for the incumbent's party are not included. Incumbents who did not run for re-election have parentheses around their name.
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable">

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="California">California</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: California">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2010_House_elections-California.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/2010_House_elections-California.svg/220px-2010_House_elections-California.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="350" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/2010_House_elections-California.svg/330px-2010_House_elections-California.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/2010_House_elections-California.svg/440px-2010_House_elections-California.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="762" data-file-height="1213" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:2010_House_elections-California.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>California's results</div></div></div>

<td style="background-color:#B0CEFF" data-sort-value="-13">D+13

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Colorado">Colorado</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Colorado">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Georgia">Georgia</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Georgia">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2010_House_Georgia.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/2010_House_Georgia.svg/220px-2010_House_Georgia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="223" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/2010_House_Georgia.svg/330px-2010_House_Georgia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/2010_House_Georgia.svg/440px-2010_House_Georgia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="962" data-file-height="977" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:2010_House_Georgia.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Georgia's results</div></div></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Indiana">Indiana</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Indiana">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Kentucky">Kentucky</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Kentucky">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2010_House_Kentucky.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/2010_House_Kentucky.svg/220px-2010_House_Kentucky.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="120" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/2010_House_Kentucky.svg/330px-2010_House_Kentucky.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/2010_House_Kentucky.svg/440px-2010_House_Kentucky.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="995" data-file-height="542" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:2010_House_Kentucky.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kentucky's results</div></div></div>

<td>Incumbent re-elected.
</td>
<td nowrap=""><div class="plainlist">

</td></tr></tbody></table>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Massachusetts">Massachusetts</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Massachusetts">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2010_House_elections_Massachusetts.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/2010_House_elections_Massachusetts.svg/220px-2010_House_elections_Massachusetts.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="117" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/2010_House_elections_Massachusetts.svg/330px-2010_House_elections_Massachusetts.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/2010_House_elections_Massachusetts.svg/440px-2010_House_elections_Massachusetts.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1092" data-file-height="582" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:2010_House_elections_Massachusetts.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Massachusetts's results</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections_in_Massachusetts" title="2010 United States House of Representatives elections in Massachusetts">2010 United States House of Representatives elections in Massachusetts</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_Representatives_from_Massachusetts" title="List of United States Representatives from Massachusetts">List of United States Representatives from Massachusetts</a></div>

<th><span data-sort-value="Massachusetts01&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/Massachusetts%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="Massachusetts&#39;s 1st congressional district">Massachusetts&#160;1</a></span>
</th>
<td style="background-color:#B0CEFF" data-sort-value="-14">D+14
</td>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Michigan">Michigan</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Michigan">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Minnesota">Minnesota</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Minnesota">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections_in_Minnesota" title="2010 United States House of Representatives elections in Minnesota">2010 United States House of Representatives elections in Minnesota</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_Representatives_from_Minnesota" title="List of United States Representatives from Minnesota">List of United States Representatives from Minnesota</a></div>
<table class="wikitable sortable">


<tbody><tr>
<th colspan="2">District
</th>
<th colspan="3">Incumbent
</th>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Missouri">Missouri</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Missouri">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections_in_Missouri" title="2010 United States House of Representatives elections in Missouri">2010 United States House of Representatives elections in Missouri</a></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="New_Mexico">New Mexico</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: New Mexico">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="New_York">New York</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=50" title="Edit section: New York">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<ul><li><img alt="Green tick" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Green_check.svg/13px-Green_check.svg.png" decoding="async" width="13" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Green_check.svg/20px-Green_check.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Green_check.svg/26px-Green_check.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="600" /><span style="display:none">Y</span> <b><a href="/wiki/Louise_Slaughter" title="Louise Slaughter">Louise Slaughter</a></b> (Democratic) 64.9%</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Jill_Rowland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jill Rowland (page does not exist)">Jill Rowland</a> (Republican) 35.1%</li></ul>
</div>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><span data-sort-value="New York29&#160;!"><a href="/wiki/New_York%27s_29th_congressional_district" title="New York&#39;s 29th congressional district">New York&#160;29</a></span>
</th>
<td style="background-color:#FFB6B6" data-sort-value="5">R+5
</td>
<td colspan="3">Vacant
</td>
<td style="background-color:#FFB6B6"><b>Republican gain</b>
</td>
<td nowrap=""><div class="plainlist">
<ul><li><img alt="Green tick" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Green_check.svg/13px-Green_check.svg.png" decoding="async" width="13" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Green_check.svg/20px-Green_check.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Green_check.svg/26px-Green_check.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="600" /><span style="display:none">Y</span> <b><a href="/wiki/Tom_Reed_(mayor)" class="mw-redirect" title="Tom Reed (mayor)">Tom Reed</a></b> (Republican) 56.6%</li>
<li>Matthew Zeller (Democratic) 43.4%</li></ul>
</div>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul><li>Democrat <a href="/wiki/Eric_Massa" title="Eric Massa">Eric Massa</a> resigned on March 8, 2010. A <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_New_York%27s_29th_congressional_district_election&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 New York&#39;s 29th congressional district election (page does not exist)">special election</a> for the remainder of his term in the 111th Congress was held on the same day as the general election, which Reed won.</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="North_Carolina">North Carolina</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=51" title="Edit section: North Carolina">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="North_Dakota">North Dakota</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=52" title="Edit section: North Dakota">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Oklahoma">Oklahoma</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=54" title="Edit section: Oklahoma">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Oregon">Oregon</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=55" title="Edit section: Oregon">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="South_Carolina">South Carolina</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections&amp;action=edit&amp;section=58" title="Edit section: South Carolina">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
